etymologies: late Middle English: from an Anglo-Norman French variant of Old Northern French gaif, probably of Scandinavian origin. Early use was often in waif and stray, as a legal term denoting a piece of property found and, if unclaimed, falling to the lord of the manor

definitions: a homeless, neglected, or abandoned person, especially a child

examples.text: she is foster mother to various waifs and strays

definitions: a young person who is thin and looks unhealthy or uncared for

examples.text: a little shop presided over by a Gothic waif in purple eyeshadow and lipstick
